elements.content: For Mn(II)-adc (adc = acetylene dicarboxylate) chemistry, diversity of product formation is demonstrated with five similar hexadentate polypyridyl ancillary ligands differing in methylene chain lengths between the alkyl nitrogens, such as tpen (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,2-diaminoethane), 1,2-tppn (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,2-diaminopropane), tppn (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,3-diaminopropane), tpbn (N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diaminobutane), and tppen (N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,5-diaminopentane). Five new compounds, [Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2]·2(solvent)} n (solvent = H2O, 1a; solvent = CH3OH, 1b), [Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6](adc)2·3H2O (2), [Mn2(adc)(1,2-tppn)2](ClO4)2·2(solvent) (solvent = H2O, 3a; solvent = CH3CN, 3b), [Mn2(adc)(tpen)2](ClO4)2·2(solvent) (solvent = H2O, 4a; solvent = CH3CN, 4b), and {[Mn2(adc)(tppen)(H2O)4](adc)·4H2O} n (5), have been isolated in good yields from the self-assembly reactions of raw materials at ambient conditions and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, IR and Raman spectroscopy, ESI mass spectrometry, single crystal and powder X-ray diffraction, and thermogravimetric analysis. Compound 1b with hexacoordinated Mn(II) centers is a three-dimensional (3D) metal–organic coordination network (MOCN) held together by strong hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions. Compound 2 with hexacoordinated Mn(II) centers is a 3D supramolecular assembly comprised of Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6 dinuclear subunits, lattice water molecules, and adc anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions. On the other hand, compounds 3b and 4b are the first examples of heptacoordinated Mn(II) complexes where the two Mn(II) centers are bridged by a dicarboxylate. Compound 5 is a one-dimensional coordination polymer comprised of the Mn2(tppen)(H2O)4 dinuclear subunits and the adc group that is further connected via both hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions. This is a rare example of having adc as a linker and a counteranion in the same compound.

On the other hand, compounds 3b and 4b are the first examples of heptacoordinated Mn(II) complexes where the two Mn(II) centers are bridged by a dicarboxylate. elements.content: In the past 15 years, a large number of metal–organic coordination networks (MOCNs) have been designed and developed for their diverse structural aesthetics and for a variety of potential applications in catalysis, separation, sensors, gas storage, luminescent materials, ion exchange, magnetism, etc. Some of these MOCNs provide examples of 2D or 3D coordination architectures with very unusual topologies. Further association of the 1D or 2D MOCNs through strong or weak hydrogen bonds, π–π stacking of aromatic moieties, C–H···O interactions, etc., generates supramolecular assemblies of higher dimensions. These MOCNs are prepared from a variety of metal centers or metal atom clusters and multiatom organic linkers. Ancillary ligands that are part of metal centers play an important role in the formation of MOCNs as the number of open sites available at the metal center depends on the denticity and binding of the ancillary ligand, which determines the dimensionality of the MOCN. Additionally, the use of ancillary ligands provides a way to have better solubility of the MOCNs than those with mostly carboxylates. However, it is a challenge with a polydentate ancillary ligand, which itself can satisfy the usual hexacoordination of a divalent transition metal ion such as Mn(II), to prevent the formation of a 1:1 discrete molecule (in case of a hexadentate ligand) instead of the desired polymeric MOCN. Thus the selection of ancillary ligands along with the multiatom organic linkers is crucial in forming the desired MOCNs. In most cases, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method has been employed to synthesize such materials. However, this synthetic route has some limitations, such as poor stability of some carboxylate linkers at high temperature. Therefore, making MOCNs under ambient conditions is an attractive route for its simplicity as well as generalization for similar systems.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past 15 years, a large number of metal-organic coordination networks (MOCNs) have been designed and developed for their diverse structural aesthetics and for a variety of potential applications in catalysis, separation, sensors, gas storage, luminescent materials, ion exchange, magnetism, etc. Some of these MOCNs provide examples of 2D or 3D coordination architectures with very unusual topologies. Further association of the 1D or 2D MOCNs through strong or weak hydrogen bonds, π-π stacking of aromatic moieties, C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions, etc., generates supramolecular assemblies of higher dimensions. These MOCNs are prepared from a variety of metal centers or metal atom clusters and multiatom organic linkers. Ancillary ligands that are part of metal centers play an important role in the formation of MOCNs as the number of open sites available at the metal center depends on the denticity and binding of the ancillary ligand, which determines the dimensionality of the MOCN. Additionally, the use of ancillary ligands provides a way to have better solubility of the MOCNs than those with mostly carboxylates. However, it is a challenge with a polydentate ancillary ligand, which itself can satisfy the usual hexacoordination of a divalent transition metal ion such as Mn(II), to prevent the formation of a 1:1 discrete molecule (in case of a hexadentate ligand) instead of the desired polymeric MOCN. Thus the selection of ancillary ligands along with the multiatom organic linkers is crucial in forming the desired MOCNs. In most cases, the hydrothermal/solvothermal method has been employed to synthesize such materials. However, this synthetic route has some limitations, such as poor stability of some carboxylate linkers at high temperature. Therefore, making MOCNs under ambient conditions is an attractive route for its simplicity as well as generalization for similar systems.

elements.content: For our efforts in designing and synthesizing new MOCNs with divalent transition metal ions, we are currently utilizing polydentate ancillary ligands and multiatom carboxylate linkers. A systematic study of the hexadentate polypyridyl ligands differing in the methylene chain length between the alkyl nitrogens, such as tpen (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,2-diaminoethane), 1,2-tppn (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,2-diaminopropane), tppn (N,N,N′,N′-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,3-diaminopropane), tpbn (N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diaminobutane), and tppen (N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,5-diaminopentane) (see Figure ), with the Mn(II) ion has been carried out to show the effect of the methylene chain length on the formation of diverse MOCNs. Among the dicarboxylates, cheap and readily available acetylene dicarboxylate is chosen for its unique properties in generating such products: (a) much smaller steric hindrance compared with other carboxylates with organic moieties having a double bond, such as fumarate or maleate, or with an aromatic ring due to its linearity and the absence of hydrogen atoms attached to the carbon skeleton and (b) the reactive triple bond that would allow further postsynthesis chemical modifications, such as attaching other molecules to it or performing photochemical reactions. Our focus on acetylene dicarboxylate is in one-pot synthesis of new MOCNs under ambient conditions because hydrothermal conditions are not suitable for its poor stability at high temperatures.

elements.content: In this contribution, we report a one-pot synthesis via self-assembly of starting materials under similar reaction conditions and structural characterization of diverse products isolated for the above-mentioned hexadentate ligands: a 3D supramolecular assembly comprised of 2D layers of {[Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2]·2(solvent)} n (solvent = H2O, 1a; solvent = CH3OH, 1b) via strong hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions; a 3D supramolecular assembly, [Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6](adc)2·3H2O (2) consisting of Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6 subunits, lattice water molecules, and adc anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions; the discrete dinuclear compounds [Mn2(adc)(1,2-tppn)2](ClO4)2·2(solvent) (solvent = H2O, 3a; solvent = CH3CN, 3b) and [Mn2(adc)(tpen)2](ClO4)2·2(solvent) (solvent = H2O, 4a; solvent = CH3CN, 4b); a 3D supramolecular assembly of 1D chains of {[Mn2(adc)(tppen)2(H2O)4](adc)·4H2O} n (5). Their spectroscopic properties and thermal behavior are also reported.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and were used as received, without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. While the tpen, 1,2-tppn and tppn ligands were prepared by modifying the literature procedures, simplified procedures with high yields for tpbn and tppen are reported below.

elements.content:
Caution! In this study metal perchlorates were used without any problem but special care should be taken to handle such salts, which are dangerous.

Physical Measurements

The 1H NMR spectra of all ligands were obtained in CDCl3 solution at 25 °C on a Bruker ARX-400 spectrometer; chemical shifts are reported relative to the residual solvent signals. The elemental analysis (C, H, N) was carried out using a Mettler CHNS analyzer, thermogravimetric analysis was carried out from 25 to 500 °C (at a heating rate of 10 °C/min) under dinitrogen atmosphere on a Mettler 851 E, and ESI mass spectrometry was performed using Thermo Scientific LTQ XL LC-MS instrument for the 50–2000 amu range. IR spectra were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 range on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum I spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw InVia Raman microscope equipped with a 785 nm high-power near-infrared laser working at 300 mW power and a Renishaw CCD detector. Analysis of the Raman spectra were performed in reflection mode on powder samples placed on the sample stage and aligned in optical path by using a camera with 10–50% laser power and by using 20–50× optics in the range of 500–4000 cm–1.

elements.content: To a solution of 16.9 g (0.1 mol) of picolylchloride hydrochloride in 85 mL of water in a 250 mL three-neck round-bottom flask (RBF), 2.5 mL (0.05 mol) of 1,4-diaminobutane was added through a funnel at once. The mixture was heated to 40 °C using a water bath. Sodium hydroxide (10 M, 20 mL) taken in a 25 mL side arm addition funnel was added to the above reaction mixture over an hour with continuous stirring while maintaining the temperature between 40 and 50 °C. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature with further stirring for 1.5 h. The resulting red mother liquor was decanted off, and 50 mL of water was added to the dark brown lumps in the flask. After stirring for half an hour, an off-white solid product was obtained via filtration, washed with water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 82%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.458 (q, 4H), 2.099 (t, 4H), 3.725 (s, 8H), 7.062 (t, 4H), 7.449 (d, 4H), 7.557 (t, 4H), 8.430 (d, 4H). Mp: 127 °C. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [(tpbn)H]+, 453.6; found, 453.4.

To a solution of 16.9 g (0.1 mol) of picolylchloride hydrochloride in 85 mL of water in a 250 mL three-neck round-bottom flask (RBF), 2.5 mL (0.05 mol) of 1,4-diaminobutane was added through a funnel at once. The mixture was heated to 40 °C using a water bath. Sodium hydroxide (10 M, 20 mL) taken in a 25 mL side arm addition funnel was added to the above reaction mixture over an hour with continuous stirring while maintaining the temperature between 40 and 50 °C. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature with further stirring for 1.5 h. The resulting red mother liquor was decanted off, and 50 mL of water was added to the dark brown lumps in the flask. After stirring for half an hour, an off-white solid product was obtained via filtration, washed with water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 82%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.458 (q, 4H), 2.099 (t, 4H), 3.725 (s, 8H), 7.062 (t, 4H), 7.449 (d, 4H), 7.557 (t, 4H), 8.430 (d, 4H). Mp: 127 °C. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [(tpbn)H]+, 453.6; found, 453.4.

elements.content: Step 1, to a methanolic solution of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (432 mg (4 mmol) in 6 mL of methanol) in a 25 mL two-neck RBF, 234 μL (2 mmol) of 1,5-diaminopentane was added, and the mixture was stirred for 2 h. An excess of sodium borohydride (1.5 equiv) was added slowly to the above solution at 0 °C and stirred for another 2.5 h. The resulting reduced schiff base was isolated from the reaction mixture by extracting with chloroform followed by drying with MgSO4 and removal of solvent. Step 2, to an aqueous solution of the reduced schiff base obtained in step 1 (568 mg (1.97 mmol) in 10 mL of water) in a 25 mL RBF, 652.5 mg (3.95 mmol) of solid picolylchloride hydrochloride was added. A sodium hydroxide solution (0.32 g in 2 mL water) was added to the above mixture in a dropwise manner and was stirred for a day. Extraction of the product with chloroform followed by the removal of the solvent under vacuum resulted in a light orange solid. Yield: 70%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.291 (m, 2H), 1.490 (m, 4H), 2.501 (t, 4H), 4.685 (s, 8H), 7.230 (t, 4H), 7.470 (d, 4H), 7.707 (t, 4H), 8.581 (d, 4H). Mp: 59 °C. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [(tppen)H]+, 467.6; found, 467.4.

elements.content: In a 25 mL RBF, 127 mg (0.5 mmol) of Mn(ClO4)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol. To this was added a solution of K2adc (prepared by taking 57.0 mg (0.5 mmol) of acetylene dicarboxylic acid and 56 mg (1 mmol) of potassium hydroxide in 2 mL of MeOH and 8 mL of water) followed by 113 mg (0.25 mmol) of solid tpbn. After stirring for 15 min, a white precipitate appeared. The reaction mixture was stirred for another 4 h at room temperature. A white solid was collected via filtration, washed with methanol and water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 123 mg (55.6%).
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of {[Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2]⋅2H2O} n  (1a)

Method I

In a 25 mL RBF, 127 mg (0.5 mmol) of Mn(ClO4)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol. To this was added a solution of K2adc (prepared by taking 57.0 mg (0.5 mmol) of acetylene dicarboxylic acid and 56 mg (1 mmol) of potassium hydroxide in 2 mL of MeOH and 8 mL of water) followed by 113 mg (0.25 mmol) of solid tpbn. After stirring for 15 min, a white precipitate appeared. The reaction mixture was stirred for another 4 h at room temperature. A white solid was collected via filtration, washed with methanol and water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 123 mg (55.6%).

elements.content: In a 25 mL RBF, 60.2 mg (0.25 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol and 56.5 mg (0.125 mmol) of solid tpbn was added to it. Solid H2adc (14.2 mg, 0.125 mmol) was added to the resulting clear solution, and a white precipitate was formed under stirring for 2 h. The mixture was stirred further for 4 h to obtain a white solid that was filtered, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 60 mg (54.0%).
elements.clean_text:
Method II

In a 25 mL RBF, 60.2 mg (0.25 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol and 56.5 mg (0.125 mmol) of solid tpbn was added to it. Solid H2adc (14.2 mg, 0.125 mmol) was added to the resulting clear solution, and a white precipitate was formed under stirring for 2 h. The mixture was stirred further for 4 h to obtain a white solid that was filtered, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 60 mg (54.0%).

elements.content: Since the compound was practically insoluble in most of the solvents, single crystals of {1·2CH3OH} n (1b) were obtained by direct layering of reactants. Thus the formula obtained from the X-ray single crystal studies differs only in terms of solvates from that for all other characterizations done with the white solid collected from either method I or II.

elements.content: It can be prepared following either method I or method II described above for 1a. As is the case for 1a, the product formation is independent of the Mn(II) salt used. Therefore, one method is reported here. In a 10 mL RBF, 30.6 mg (0.125 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2, 27.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of tppn, and 14.2 mg (0.125 mmol) of H2adc were dissolved in 4 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h and then evaporated to dryness. The resulting residue was treated with a 1:1 mixture of acetonitrile and toluene (2 mL) to remove acetic acid completely, which provided an off-white solid. Yield: 41.5 mg (69.0%). Anal. Calcd for C35H48Mn2N6O17 (MW 934.67): C, 44.96; H, 5.13; N, 8.99. Found: C, 44.48; H, 4.67; N, 8.61. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3387, 3230, 1603, 1330, 775, 665. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [{Mn(tppn)}(adc)H]+, 606.56; found, 606.24.

Synthesis of [Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6](adc)2⋅3H2O (2)

It can be prepared following either method I or method II described above for 1a. As is the case for 1a, the product formation is independent of the Mn(II) salt used. Therefore, one method is reported here. In a 10 mL RBF, 30.6 mg (0.125 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2, 27.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of tppn, and 14.2 mg (0.125 mmol) of H2adc were dissolved in 4 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h and then evaporated to dryness. The resulting residue was treated with a 1:1 mixture of acetonitrile and toluene (2 mL) to remove acetic acid completely, which provided an off-white solid. Yield: 41.5 mg (69.0%). Anal. Calcd for C35H48Mn2N6O17 (MW 934.67): C, 44.96; H, 5.13; N, 8.99. Found: C, 44.48; H, 4.67; N, 8.61. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm-1): 3387, 3230, 1603, 1330, 775, 665. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [{Mn(tppn)}(adc)H]+, 606.56; found, 606.24.

elements.content: Following the practices of this laboratory published earlier, initial crystal evaluation and data collection were performed on a Kappa APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector (with the crystal-to-detector distance fixed at 60 mm) and sealed-tube monochromated Mo Kα radiation using the program APEX2. By use of the program SAINT for the integration of the data, reflection profiles were fitted, and values of F 2 and σ(F 2) for each reflection were obtained. Data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The subroutine XPREP was used for the processing of data, which included determination of space group, application of an absorption correction (SADABS), merging of data, and generation of files necessary for solution and refinement. The crystal structures were solved and refined using SHELX 97. In each case, the space group was chosen based on systematic absences and confirmed by the successful refinement of the structure. Positions of most of the non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from a direct methods solution. Several full-matrix least-squares/difference Fourier cycles were performed, locating the remainder of the non-hydrogen atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms, except where indicated otherwise, were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In the case of 2, one oxygen atom of one of the carboxylate groups in one adc ligand was found to be disordered over two locations and was refined with a 0.5 occupancy factor each; in the final difference Fourier map, other than a residual peak of 1.246 e/Å3 that was located at 0.94 Å away from this oxygen atom, there was no other significant peak >1 e/Å3. Several attempts that included collecting data at 240 K (there was a trade-off between lowering temperature further and having not lost the integrity of the crystal) did not provide any better results than reported here. All hydrogen atoms except those for one water molecule in 2 were placed in ideal positions and refined as riding atoms with individual isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic parameters and basic information pertaining to data collection and structure refinement for all compounds are summarized in Table . All figures were drawn using Mercury V 3.0 and OLEX2, and hydrogen bonding parameters were generated using PLATON. The final positional and thermal parameters of the non-hydrogen atoms for all structures are listed in the CIF files ().

By use of the program SAINT for the integration of the data, reflection profiles were fitted, and values of F 2 and σ(F 2) for each reflection were obtained. Data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The crystal structures were solved and refined using SHELX 97. In each case, the space group was chosen based on systematic absences and confirmed by the successful refinement of the structure. Positions of most of the non-hydrogen atoms were obtained from a direct methods solution. Several full-matrix least-squares/difference Fourier cycles were performed, locating the remainder of the non-hydrogen atoms. All non-hydrogen atoms, except where indicated otherwise, were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. In the case of 2, one oxygen atom of one of the carboxylate groups in one adc ligand was found to be disordered over two locations and was refined with a 0.5 occupancy factor each; in the final difference Fourier map, other than a residual peak of 1.246 e/Å3 that was located at 0.94 Å away from this oxygen atom, there was no other significant peak >1 e/Å3. Several attempts that included collecting data at 240 K (there was a trade-off between lowering temperature further and having not lost the integrity of the crystal) did not provide any better results than reported here. All hydrogen atoms except those for one water molecule in 2 were placed in ideal positions and refined as riding atoms with individual isotropic displacement parameters. Crystallographic parameters and basic information pertaining to data collection and structure refinement for all compounds are summarized in Table . All figures were drawn using Mercury V 3.0 and OLEX2, and hydrogen bonding parameters were generated using PLATON. elements.content: Data were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a 3 KW sealed tube Cu Kα X-ray radiation (generator power settings, 40 kV and 40 mA) and a DTex Ultra detector using parallel beam geometry (2.5° primary and secondary solar slits, 0.5° divergence slit with 10 mm height limit slit). Each sample ground into a fine powder using a mortar and a pestle was put on a glass sample holder that was placed on the sample rotation stage (120 rpm) attachment of the instrument. The data were collected over an angle range of 5° to 50° with a scanning speed of 1° per minute with a 0.01° step and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) reduction for the metals.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Studies

Data were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a 3 KW sealed tube Cu Kα X-ray radiation (generator power settings, 40 kV and 40 mA) and a DTex Ultra detector using parallel beam geometry (2.5° primary and secondary solar slits, 0.5° divergence slit with 10 mm height limit slit). Each sample ground into a fine powder using a mortar and a pestle was put on a glass sample holder that was placed on the sample rotation stage (120 rpm) attachment of the instrument. The data were collected over an angle range of 5° to 50° with a scanning speed of 1° per minute with a 0.01° step and X-ray fluorescence (XRF) reduction for the metals.

elements.content: Although the syntheses of the hexadentate ligands used in this study were reported in the literature, improved syntheses of tpen, 1,2-tppn, and tppn resulted in the isolation of solid products in shorter time. Interestingly, the synthesis of tpbn utilizing the method used in this report was never described fully with no information about its yield and purity as it was always referred to the method for tppn. All other reports for the synthesis of tpbn in good yields required either (a) the use of halogenated solvents and handling of expensive tris(acetoxy)borohydrides under inert conditions as well as extensive workup including column chromatography or (b) an expensive phase transfer catalyst and a long reaction time (days). On the other hand, for a total of 2.5 h reaction time (see the ), tpbn is isolated in 82% yield (with no detectable impurity based on 1H NMR data and a sharp melting point) using water as solvent and, more importantly, without the use of column chromatography. Similarly, tppen is prepared and isolated in good yield and purity under ambient conditions and without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Although the syntheses of the hexadentate ligands used in this study were reported in the literature, improved syntheses of tpen, 1,2-tppn, and tppn resulted in the isolation of solid products in shorter time. Interestingly, the synthesis of tpbn utilizing the method used in this report was never described fully with no information about its yield and purity as it was always referred to the method for tppn. All other reports for the synthesis of tpbn in good yields required either (a) the use of halogenated solvents and handling of expensive tris(acetoxy)borohydrides under inert conditions as well as extensive workup including column chromatography or (b) an expensive phase transfer catalyst and a long reaction time (days). On the other hand, for a total of 2.5 h reaction time (see the ), tpbn is isolated in 82% yield (with no detectable impurity based on 1H NMR data and a sharp melting point) using water as solvent and, more importantly, without the use of column chromatography. Similarly, tppen is prepared and isolated in good yield and purity under ambient conditions and without further purification.

elements.content: Scheme summarizes the synthesis of all five compounds reported here. {[Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2]·2H2O} n (1a) was prepared and isolated as a colorless solid from the self-assembly reaction of Mn(ClO4)2·and dipotassium acetylene dicarboxylate (in a 1:1 ratio) in a methanol–water mixture followed by the addition of half equivalent of tpbn under ambient conditions. Alternatively, 1a can be prepared using Mn(OAc)2·as the starting material indicating no effect of the Mn(II) source on the product formation. When the same procedure similar to 1a using Mn(OAc)2·4H2O was followed for the tpen, 1,2-tppn, tppn, and tppen ligands, different products are formed. A supramolecular assembly [Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6](adc)2·3H2O (2), consisting of Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6 dinuclear subunits, lattice water molecules, and adc anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions, is the product for the tppn ligand. Discrete dinuclear complexes [Mn2(adc)(1,2-tppn)2](ClO4)2·3H2O (3a) and [Mn2(adc) (tpen)2](ClO4)2·2H2O (4b) are formed where each Mn(II) center is heptacoordinated. On the other hand, for the tppen ligand, a 3D supramolecular assembly {[Mn2(adc)(tppen)(H2O)4](adc)·4H2O} n (5) is isolated where adc is found to be a linker as well as a counteranion in the same structure. It should be noted here that the use of Mn(ClO4)2 as the starting material for 2, 3a, 4b, and 5 gives the same product and only reduces the isolated yield by a few percent. Therefore, the appropriate method is described in the that suited the final workup for isolating the product with the best yields. This difference in their formulation can be easily observed by comparing their FTIR spectra and solubility behavior. Compound 1a is a neutral species with two adc ligands bridging the Mn(II) ions in a bis(monodentate) fashion. Although the formula of 1a and 2 contain two adc molecules, the FTIR spectra clearly show the difference in its stretching frequencies indicating its inclusion in the primary coordination sphere in 1a while acting as a counteranion in 2. In 5, the presence of both coordinated (in a monodentate fashion) adc and uncoordinated adc in its FTIR spectrum could be compared with those for 1a and 2. Dinuclear complexes 3a and 4a have two perchlorate counteranions, which show characteristic features in the FTIR spectroscopy. Compound 1a was found to be insoluble in almost all organic solvents, whereas 2 and 5 were soluble in water, and 3a and 4a were soluble in acetonitrile. Further evidence for the diversity of such product formation due to a subtle change in the methylene chain length between the alkyl nitrogens of these ligands is provided with the help of X-ray crystallography, which is discussed next.

elements.content: Crystals of 1b suitable for the single crystal X-ray study were grown from the direct layering of the reactants because the compound was practically insoluble in all common organic solvents. Crystals of 2 and 5 were grown from the evaporation of an aqueous solution, while those of 3b and 4b were obtained by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of the respective compound.
elements.clean_text:
Single Crystal Structure Analyses

Crystals of 1b suitable for the single crystal X-ray study were grown from the direct layering of the reactants because the compound was practically insoluble in all common organic solvents. Crystals of 2 and 5 were grown from the evaporation of an aqueous solution, while those of 3b and 4b were obtained by slow evaporation of acetonitrile solution of the respective compound.

elements.content: Compound 1a crystallizes in the triclinic P1̅ space group (No. 2) with an inversion center in the middle of the dinuclear unit consisting of two Mn(II) centers bridged by two adc groups, each of which binds in a monodentate syn–syn fashion. The unit cell packing diagram for 1b is shown in Figure S1 of the . The geometry around each Mn(II) center is distorted octahedral and is surrounded by three nitrogens of tpbn, one water molecule, and two oxygen atoms of two adc (see Figure ). There are several metal–adc complexes without any ancillary ligand showing 2D and 3D networks. However, none of these complexes shows binding of adc similar to that in 1b. On the other hand, a series of supramolecular assemblies, [Mn2(adc)2(bpta)2(H2O)2]·5H2O and its derivatives (where bpta = N,N-bis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-tert-butylamine), recently reported from this laboratory have the same bis(adc) core found in 1b.

elements.content: The tpbn ligand spans between two such dinuclear subunits forming the spiral coordination polymer. A perspective view of 1b is shown in Figure (left). A space filling model of 1b depicting the repeated pores (size 7.662 Å × 4.530 Å) in the polymeric structure is also shown in Figure (right). A fully labeled figure of 1 excluding methanol is included in the (Figure S6). The alkyl nitrogen of each half of the tpbn ligand is trans to one of the adc, whereas one of the pyridine nitrogens is trans to the bound water molecule, and the other pyridine nitrogen is trans to the second adc. The selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Table S1, . The Mn–Npy distance (2.2870(15)–2.2901(16) Å) is shorter than Mn–Nalkyl distance (2.3381(15) Å). The two Mn–Ocarb distances are found to be different, Mn–O2 (2.1644(13) Å) and Mn–O4 (2.1029(13) Å). The Mn–Owater (2.1697(13) Å) distances are similar to the values usually observed in hexacoordinated Mn(II) complexes of similar ancillary ligands. The O–Mn–Npyridine angles are 160.70(5)° and 162.78(5)°. The O–Mn–Namine angles are all in the same range, from 94.88(5)° to 154.12(5)°. The values observed for the acetylene group confirm that its triple bond character is retained in 1b: C16–C18–C17 and C18–C16–C15 angles are close to linearity (ranges from 176.71(19)° to 176.82(19)°) and C–C triple bond distance is 1.195(3) Å (see the section below).

elements.content: The coordinated water molecule (O1) on the Mn center of 1b is strongly hydrogen bonded in an intramolecular fashion (O···O distance 2.670 (2) Å) to the uncoordinated O atom of the adc molecule (O3), which is further hydrogen bonded (O···O distance 2.770(2) Å) to the O atom (O6) of methanol solvent (see Figure ). A labeled version of this figure is included in the (Figure S7). Through intermolecular hydrogen bonding, the bound water molecule (O1) further connects the uncoordinated O atom of the adc molecule (O5) of the next asymmetric unit (O···O distance 2.649(2) Å) forming the supramolecular network of the polymeric Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2 layer in a direction with an angle of 45° to the latter. Hydrogen bonding distances found in 1b are summarized in Table . There are π–π interactions between the pyridine rings of the tpbn ligands (centroid–centroid distance 3.766) of the two spiral 2D chains resulting in the formation of a 3D supramolecular assembly as shown in Figure . To demonstrate the strength of H-bonding in 1b, its single crystal was subjected to variable-temperature X-ray studies. In order to make it methanol solvent free, a single crystal was slowly heated to 323 K (50 °C) at the rate of 40 K/h using the Oxford LT device attached to the diffractometer. When the temperature was raised above 323 K, it was found that the crystal lost its integrity. The full data collection was carried on this crystal at 323 K, and it was found that one of the two methanol molecules remained within the lattice. Its dehydration upon heating can further be followed from the TGA (vide infra).

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/n space group (No. 14). The unit cell packing diagram for 2 is provided in Figure S2 of the . Like 1b, the tppn ligand in 2 spans between two Mn(II) centers, which are hexacoordinated (Mn···Mn distance 7.037 Å). Each Mn(II) center is coordinated with three water molecules and three nitrogen atoms from one-half of the tppn ligand as shown in Figure . A fully labeled figure with counteranions and water of crystallization is included in the (Figure S8). The selected bond distances and angles are summarized in Table S1, . The Mn–Npy distance (2.237(3)–2.262(3) Å) is shorter than the Mn–Nalkyl distance (2.336(3)–2.362(3) Å). The Mn–Owater (2.144(3)–2.222(3) Å) distances are similar to the values found in 1b. The O–Mn–Npyridine angles range from 84.73(12)° to 91.25 (13)° and 153.74(12)° to 177.17(13)°. The O–Mn–Namine angles are in the range of 86.94 (12)° to 108.48 (12)° and 161.59(13)° to 166.84(13)°. The values observed for the acetylene group in 2 are similar to those found in 1b: C30–C29–C28 and C34–C33–C32 angles are close to linearity (ranges from 174.3° to 179°) and C–C triple bond distances range from 1.187 to 1.200 Å. Very few examples are known in which a Mn(II) center has three or more water molecules. The coordinated water molecules prohibit adc anions from coordinating to the Mn(II) centers in 2. Unlike in 1b, the adc acts as counteranion in 2. Prior to this work, there are only two reports in the literature where the adc is not part of the first coordination sphere of the transition metal ion. However, the reported examples are coordination polymers where the [Mn(H2O)4]2+ moieties are connected with the 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane or 4,4′-bpy ligand. Thus the coordination of three water molecules to each Mn(II) center of 2 in the presence of a hexadentate ligand is unprecedented. These three coordinated water molecules, adc anions, and lattice water molecules are connected through extensive H-bonding as shown in Figure ; a labeled figure is included in the (Figure S9). Hydrogen bonding parameters found in 2 are summarized in Table . The orientation of coordinated water molecules on each Mn(II) center is different. This resulted in different H-bonding modes of two adc anions with coordinated water molecules. In order to show the difference in the two types of binding modes of the adc anions in 2, these are colored in green and yellow in Figure . The bonding of the adc anions in green color to the coordinated water molecules can be visualized as the two adc anions connect two dimanganese subunits together resulting in the formation of a channel (Mn···Mn distance 12.026 Å). On the other hand, the adc anions in yellow color are hydrogen bonded to the coordinated water molecules to generate totally different motifs (Mn···Mn distance 8.952 Å). In the second mode, one of the carboxylate groups of each adc anion is hydrogen bonded to the lattice water molecules. Considering the fact that the direct coordination of the adc anions in 1 allows only one coordinated water molecule per Mn(II) center compared with three water molecules in 2, the formation of 1 can be through an intermediate similar to 2. Thus the isolation of 2 with one less methylene group in tppn compared with tpbn indicates that only the former can stabilize such a 3D supramolecular assembly. As mentioned in the next sections, reducing the methylene chain length to less than three, which is the case for 1,2-tppn or tpen, or increasing the methylene chain length to more than four like in tppen gives different products. This finding is helpful to understand the formation of the supramolecular assemblies, such as 1 and 2.

Compounds 3b and 4b are isostructural and crystallize in the monoclinic C2/c space group (No. 15). The unit cell packing diagrams for 3b and 4b are provided in Figure S3 and S4, respectively, of the . These are discrete dinuclear compounds (see Figures and , respectively; corresponding fully labeled figures are provided in the , Figures S10 and S11, respectively). In both cases, the Mn(II) centers are heptacoordinated. Although there are many mononuclear heptacoordinated Mn(II) complexes reported in the literature, carboxylato bridged dinuclear species are limited. An example of acetate bridged dinulcear compound with both Mn(II) centers being heptacoordinated (N6O environment) was reported for the tpen ligand several years ago. Thus 3b and 4b are the first examples of heptacoordinated dinuclear Mn(II) complexes with a combination of dicarboxylates and polydentate ancillary ligands. The striking feature in these two compounds is that even with a hexadentate ligand, such as 1,2-tppn and tpen, the Mn(II) centers are bridged by the adc linker in an anti–anti monodentate fashion. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1, . The Mn–Nalkyl distances in 3b and 4b range from 2.381(2) to 2.459(3) Å and 2.369(2) to 2.450(2)Å, respectively. These distances are comparable to those found in Mn(II) complexes of similar ancillary ligands.

This shows that the triple bond character of adc remains intact in these molecules and is not much affected by the increase in coordination number of the Mn(II) centers in 1b and 3b or 4b.

elements.content: Compound 5 crystallizes in the monoclinic P2/c space group (No. 13). The unit cell packing diagram for 5 is shown in Figure S5 of the . Unlike 1b and 2, it is a 1D coordination polymer where the adc group links the Mn2(tppen)(H2O)4 dinuclear subunits (Mn···Mn distance 9.468 Å) with the tppen ligand spanning between two Mn(II) centers (Mn···Mn distance 10.980 Å). Compound 5 is unexpected for two reasons: with more than four methylene chain length, one would expect a derivative of 1b, and if the odd number of methylene groups has any effect, a derivative of 2 should be the product. Each hexacoordinated Mn(II) center in 5 is surrounded by three nitrogens of tppen, two water molecules and one oxygen atom of one monodentate adc as shown in Figure (top). The alkyl nitrogen of each half of the tppen ligand is trans to the bridging adc whereas both pyridine nitrogens are trans to the bound water molecules. The selected bond distances and angles for 5 summarized in Table S1, , are similar to those for 1b and 2. Two coordinated water molecules, coordinated adc, uncoordinated adc anions, and lattice water molecules are linked through extensive H-bonding as shown in Figure (bottom); a labeled figure is included in the (Figure S12). In particular, the cyclic hexameric motif is comprised of the two coordinated water molecules from two different layers and four oxygen atoms from two different uncoordinated adc groups. Two layers of polymeric Mn2(adc)(tppen)(H2O)4 are connected to generate 2D supramolecular network with two types of Mn···Mn distances due to different connectivity of the adc; the Mn···Mn distance is 8.839 Å for 1D polymer connected via uncoordinated adc and lattice water molecules, while it is 8.410 Å for two layers that are connected via coordinated adc and lattice water molecules. Hydrogen bonding parameters found in 5 are summarized in Table . There are π–π interactions between the pyridine rings of the tppen ligands (centroid–centroid distance 3.631 Å) of the two spiral 2D chains resulting in the formation of 3D supramolecular assembly as shown in Figure .

elements.content: In this study, five hexadentate polypyridyl ancillary ligands differing in methylene chain lengths between the alkyl nitrogens have been used to investigate the formation of products in the Mn(II)–adc system under similar reaction conditions. With two methylene groups for the tpen and 1,2-tppn ligands, it is anticipated due to chelating effect to have a 1:1 complex with the Mn(II) ion; thus, the formation of 3a and 4a is not a surprise. As the chain length increased from three to four to five (tppn, tpbn, and tppen, respectively), which reduces the chelating effect, the spanning of the hexadentate ligands between two Mn(II) centers is the result in 1a, 2, and 5. However, the remaining three coordination sites on each Mn(II) center have different ligand binding (adc, water, or both) providing the diversity of product formation. With four methylene groups in tpbn, a polymeric bis(monodentate adc) bridged structure of 1 is obtained where each Mn(II) center has one water molecule. On the other hand, each Mn(II) center in 2 and 5 has three and two coordinated water molecules, respectively, allowing no coordinated adc in 2 and one coordinated adc in 5; in both cases adc acts as a counteranion. For the tppn and tppen ligands, the role of the adc anion in the product formation is important and further demonstrates the effect of the methylene chain length in determining the structure of such MOCNs.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of N-Donor Ligands

In this study, five hexadentate polypyridyl ancillary ligands differing in methylene chain lengths between the alkyl nitrogens have been used to investigate the formation of products in the Mn(II)-adc system under similar reaction conditions. With two methylene groups for the tpen and 1,2-tppn ligands, it is anticipated due to chelating effect to have a 1:1 complex with the Mn(II) ion; thus, the formation of 3a and 4a is not a surprise. As the chain length increased from three to four to five (tppn, tpbn, and tppen, respectively), which reduces the chelating effect, the spanning of the hexadentate ligands between two Mn(II) centers is the result in 1a, 2, and 5. However, the remaining three coordination sites on each Mn(II) center have different ligand binding (adc, water, or both) providing the diversity of product formation. With four methylene groups in tpbn, a polymeric bis(monodentate adc) bridged structure of 1 is obtained where each Mn(II) center has one water molecule. On the other hand, each Mn(II) center in 2 and 5 has three and two coordinated water molecules, respectively, allowing no coordinated adc in 2 and one coordinated adc in 5; in both cases adc acts as a counteranion. For the tppn and tppen ligands, the role of the adc anion in the product formation is important and further demonstrates the effect of the methylene chain length in determining the structure of such MOCNs.

elements.content: In order to confirm whether the single crystal structure corresponds to the bulk material and phase purity, powder X-ray diffraction patterns for 1–4 were recorded at room temperature. The experimental and simulated X-ray patterns for 1a, 1b, and 2 are shown in Figure S18 (). The simulated pattern for 1b matches with the experimental patterns for 1a and 1b. This confirms that the single crystal and bulk material are the same and the compound with water (1a) and methanol (1b) as solvent of crystallization are isostructural. In Figure S19 (), the experimental and simulated X-ray patterns for 3a/3b and 4a/4b are compared and show their isostructural behavior. Indexing of the powder patterns of 1–4 compounds generates unit cells that are similar to those obtained from the single crystal X-ray studies.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Data Analysis

In order to confirm whether the single crystal structure corresponds to the bulk material and phase purity, powder X-ray diffraction patterns for 1-4 were recorded at room temperature. The experimental and simulated X-ray patterns for 1a, 1b, and 2 are shown in Figure S18 (). The simulated pattern for 1b matches with the experimental patterns for 1a and 1b. This confirms that the single crystal and bulk material are the same and the compound with water (1a) and methanol (1b) as solvent of crystallization are isostructural. In Figure S19 (), the experimental and simulated X-ray patterns for 3a/3b and 4a/4b are compared and show their isostructural behavior. Indexing of the powder patterns of 1-4 compounds generates unit cells that are similar to those obtained from the single crystal X-ray studies.

elements.content: The IR spectra of 1a, 2, and 5 (see Figures S13, S14, and S17 in the , respectively) recorded in the solid state show a band centered at 3392 cm–1, which is a characteristic feature for O–H stretching frequency of the lattice water molecule. Another band in this region centered at 3203 (1), 3230 (2), and 3220 cm–1 (5) is due to bound water molecules. In contrast, there is only one band centered at 3430 and 3446 cm–1 for 3a and 4a, respectively, (see Figures S15 and S16 in the , respectively) due to lattice water molecules clearly indicating that in both these compounds Mn(II) does not have a bound water molecule. These spectra also have a series of bands between 1610 and 1310 cm–1. While some of these features are due to the tpbn ligand, bands at 1570 and 1351 cm–1 are due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylate groups of adc, respectively, in the case of 1a. A value of 219 cm–1 for the difference in the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes is indicative of monodendate binding of the carboxylate groups of adc in 1 as found in the crystal structure. For 2, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate group of the uncoordinated adc are at 1572 and 1330 cm–1, respectively. Other features in the spectra for 3a and 4a are similar to those in 1a with a shift of a few wave numbers in each case. For 5, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate group are at 1626, 1570, and 1329 cm–1, respectively, for the uncoordinated and coordinated adc. The second most important difference in the FTIR spectra for the complexes is the absence of perchlorate ion peaks in 1a (a neutral compound), 2, and 5 (with adc as counterions in both), whereas in 3a and 4a perchlorate peaks are found to be present at 1090, 623 and 1087, 623 cm–1, respectively. All but 5 were also studied by Raman spectroscopy (see Figure ); several attempts failed to obtain the Raman spectrum of 5. For 1a, it shows a peak at 2216 cm–1 for the C–C triple bond, while the other features for the tpbn ligand and the carboxylate groups of adc (1573 and 1389 cm–1) are similar to its IR spectrum. Similarly, Raman spectra of 2, 3a and 4a show peaks at 2206, 2207, and 2213 cm–1, respectively, for the C–C triple bond. However, the intensity of the peak is much lower for 2, 3a, and 4a compared with 1a. This may be explained for the fact that the association of the adc is different in these complexes. While 1a is a polymer with two adc molecules bridging between the two Mn(II) ions, 2 is a supramolecular assembly with adc not bound to the Mn(II) ions, and 3a and 4a are discrete dinuclear complexes with one bridging adc between the two Mn(II) ions. This study correlates well with findings from other characterization techniques.
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR and Raman Spectroscopy

The IR spectra of 1a, 2, and 5 (see Figures S13, S14, and S17 in the , respectively) recorded in the solid state show a band centered at 3392 cm-1, which is a characteristic feature for O-H stretching frequency of the lattice water molecule. Another band in this region centered at 3203 (1), 3230 (2), and 3220 cm-1 (5) is due to bound water molecules. In contrast, there is only one band centered at 3430 and 3446 cm-1 for 3a and 4a, respectively, (see Figures S15 and S16 in the , respectively) due to lattice water molecules clearly indicating that in both these compounds Mn(II) does not have a bound water molecule. These spectra also have a series of bands between 1610 and 1310 cm-1. While some of these features are due to the tpbn ligand, bands at 1570 and 1351 cm-1 are due to asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the carboxylate groups of adc, respectively, in the case of 1a. A value of 219 cm-1 for the difference in the asymmetric and symmetric stretching modes is indicative of monodendate binding of the carboxylate groups of adc in 1 as found in the crystal structure. For 2, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate group of the uncoordinated adc are at 1572 and 1330 cm-1, respectively. Other features in the spectra for 3a and 4a are similar to those in 1a with a shift of a few wave numbers in each case. For 5, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate group are at 1626, 1570, and 1329 cm-1, respectively, for the uncoordinated and coordinated adc. The second most important difference in the FTIR spectra for the complexes is the absence of perchlorate ion peaks in 1a (a neutral compound), 2, and 5 (with adc as counterions in both), whereas in 3a and 4a perchlorate peaks are found to be present at 1090, 623 and 1087, 623 cm-1, respectively. All but 5 were also studied by Raman spectroscopy (see Figure ); several attempts failed to obtain the Raman spectrum of 5. For 1a, it shows a peak at 2216 cm-1 for the C-C triple bond, while the other features for the tpbn ligand and the carboxylate groups of adc (1573 and 1389 cm-1) are similar to its IR spectrum. Similarly, Raman spectra of 2, 3a and 4a show peaks at 2206, 2207, and 2213 cm-1, respectively, for the C-C triple bond. However, the intensity of the peak is much lower for 2, 3a, and 4a compared with 1a. This may be explained for the fact that the association of the adc is different in these complexes. While 1a is a polymer with two adc molecules bridging between the two Mn(II) ions, 2 is a supramolecular assembly with adc not bound to the Mn(II) ions, and 3a and 4a are discrete dinuclear complexes with one bridging adc between the two Mn(II) ions. This study correlates well with findings from other characterization techniques.

elements.content: For studying the thermal stability as a function of temperature, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted for the single phase polycrystalline samples of 1a and 2 between 25 and 500 °C under dinitrogen atmosphere (see Figures S20 and S21 in the , respectively). From the multistep decomposition process for 1a, it is clearly evident that lattice water molecules are lost first followed by the coordinated water molecules and the adc linker. The first weight loss of 3.08% between 50 and 100 °C corresponds to one and a half lattice water molecules (ca. 3.15%). The second weight loss of 5.02% between 100 and 175 °C corresponds to one-half lattice water molecule and two coordinated water molecules (ca. 5.45%). The third weight loss of 33.95% between 175 and 450 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. For 2, the first weight loss of 10.90% observed between 45 and 105 °C corresponds to three free and three coordinated water molecules (ca. 11.61%). The second weight loss of 11.07% between 105 and 155 °C corresponds to decomposition of one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 12.20%). The third weight loss of 50.33% between 155 and 450 °C corresponds to three coordinated water molecules and one tppn ligand (ca.52.67%). This shows how strongly water molecules are hydrogen bonded with acetylene dicarboxylates in 2. For 5 (Figure S22 in the ), the first weight loss of 7.99% observed between 35 and 80 °C corresponds to four free water molecules (ca. 7.77%). The second weight loss of 21.14% between 80 and 190 °C corresponds to four coordinated water molecules and one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 19.70%). The third weight loss of 41.32% between 190 and 400 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. TGA of 3a and 4a were not carried out because these contain perchlorate anions. Thermal behavior of 1a, 2, and 5 are in very good agreement with X-ray studies as well as the FT-IR spectroscopic data.

elements.content: In this study, we have demonstrated the effect of the number of methylene units between the alkyl nitrogens of the hexadentate ligands on the formation of polymeric vs discrete products. Based on the self-assembly reaction of starting materials under similar reaction conditions, a 3D supramolecular network, 1b, held together by π–π interactions between the 2D layers of [Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2] n has been synthesized. With one less methylene group in tppn, a 3D supramolecular assembly, 2, comprised of Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6 dinuclear subunits, lattice water molecules, and adc anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions, is isolated. Compounds 1b and 2 are the first examples of a 3D MOCN and a 3D supramolecular assembly, respectively, where a hexadentate ancillary ligand is used. On the other hand, for the tpen and 1,2-tppn ligands with two methylene units between the alkyl nitrogen atoms, discrete compounds 3b and 4b are formed. Furthermore, depending on the ligand an observation of different coordination numbers for Mn(II) is the most striking feature. In compounds 1b and 2, each Mn(II) center is hexacoordianted, while in case of 3b and 4b, each Mn(II) center is heptacoordinated. Compounds 3b and 4b are the first examples of heptacoordinated Mn(II) complexes where the two Mn(II) centers are bridged by a dicarboxylate. Compound 5 is a rare example of having adc as a linker and a counteranion in the same structure where the adc group links the Mn2(tppen)(H2O)4 dinuclear subunits to form the 1D chains that are further connected via both hydrogen bonding and π–π interactions. Therefore, these ligands are found to play an important role in determining the coordination architectures with respect to their size, conformation, and properties. The current work has thus laid the foundation for the strategy in developing new MOCNs with targeted structures and properties. Based on the results presented in the paper, it is envisaged that further modifications on the N-donor ligands as well as choosing other metal centers will allow us to generate a series of MOCNs to understand their formation in detail.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this study, we have demonstrated the effect of the number of methylene units between the alkyl nitrogens of the hexadentate ligands on the formation of polymeric vs discrete products. Based on the self-assembly reaction of starting materials under similar reaction conditions, a 3D supramolecular network, 1b, held together by π-π interactions between the 2D layers of [Mn2(adc)2(tpbn)(H2O)2] n  has been synthesized. With one less methylene group in tppn, a 3D supramolecular assembly, 2, comprised of Mn2(tppn)(H2O)6 dinuclear subunits, lattice water molecules, and adc anions through strong hydrogen bonding interactions, is isolated. Compounds 1b and 2 are the first examples of a 3D MOCN and a 3D supramolecular assembly, respectively, where a hexadentate ancillary ligand is used. On the other hand, for the tpen and 1,2-tppn ligands with two methylene units between the alkyl nitrogen atoms, discrete compounds 3b and 4b are formed. Furthermore, depending on the ligand an observation of different coordination numbers for Mn(II) is the most striking feature. In compounds 1b and 2, each Mn(II) center is hexacoordianted, while in case of 3b and 4b, each Mn(II) center is heptacoordinated. Compounds 3b and 4b are the first examples of heptacoordinated Mn(II) complexes where the two Mn(II) centers are bridged by a dicarboxylate. Compound 5 is a rare example of having adc as a linker and a counteranion in the same structure where the adc group links the Mn2(tppen)(H2O)4 dinuclear subunits to form the 1D chains that are further connected via both hydrogen bonding and π-π interactions. Therefore, these ligands are found to play an important role in determining the coordination architectures with respect to their size, conformation, and properties. The current work has thus laid the foundation for the strategy in developing new MOCNs with targeted structures and properties. Based on the results presented in the paper, it is envisaged that further modifications on the N-donor ligands as well as choosing other metal centers will allow us to generate a series of MOCNs to understand their formation in detail.

To a solution of 16.9 g (0.1 mol) of picolylchloride hydrochloride in 85 mL of water in a 250 mL three-neck round-bottom flask (RBF), 2.5 mL (0.05 mol) of 1,4-diaminobutane was added through a funnel at once. The mixture was heated to 40 °C using a water bath. Sodium hydroxide (10 M, 20 mL) taken in a 25 mL side arm addition funnel was added to the above reaction mixture over an hour with continuous stirring while maintaining the temperature between 40 and 50 °C. The reaction mixture was then cooled to room temperature with further stirring for 1.5 h. The resulting red mother liquor was decanted off, and 50 mL of water was added to the dark brown lumps in the flask. After stirring for half an hour, an off-white solid product was obtained via filtration, washed with water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 82%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.458 (q, 4H), 2.099 (t, 4H), 3.725 (s, 8H), 7.062 (t, 4H), 7.449 (d, 4H), 7.557 (t, 4H), 8.430 (d, 4H). Mp: 127 °C. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [(tpbn)H]+, 453.6; found, 453.4.

Synthesis of <italic toggle="yes">N</italic>,<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>′,<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>″,<italic toggle="yes">N</italic>‴-Tetrakis-(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,5-diaminopentane (tppen)

Step 1, to a methanolic solution of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde (432 mg (4 mmol) in 6 mL of methanol) in a 25 mL two-neck RBF, 234 μL (2 mmol) of 1,5-diaminopentane was added, and the mixture was stirred for 2 h. An excess of sodium borohydride (1.5 equiv) was added slowly to the above solution at 0 °C and stirred for another 2.5 h. The resulting reduced schiff base was isolated from the reaction mixture by extracting with chloroform followed by drying with MgSO4 and removal of solvent. Step 2, to an aqueous solution of the reduced schiff base obtained in step 1 (568 mg (1.97 mmol) in 10 mL of water) in a 25 mL RBF, 652.5 mg (3.95 mmol) of solid picolylchloride hydrochloride was added. A sodium hydroxide solution (0.32 g in 2 mL water) was added to the above mixture in a dropwise manner and was stirred for a day. Extraction of the product with chloroform followed by the removal of the solvent under vacuum resulted in a light orange solid. Yield: 70%. 1H NMR (CDCl3): δ 1.291 (m, 2H), 1.490 (m, 4H), 2.501 (t, 4H), 4.685 (s, 8H), 7.230 (t, 4H), 7.470 (d, 4H), 7.707 (t, 4H), 8.581 (d, 4H). Mp: 59 °C. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [(tppen)H]+, 467.6; found, 467.4.

Synthesis of {[Mn<sub>2</sub>(adc)<sub>2</sub>(tpbn)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>1a</bold>)Method I

In a 25 mL RBF, 127 mg (0.5 mmol) of Mn(ClO4)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol. To this was added a solution of K2adc (prepared by taking 57.0 mg (0.5 mmol) of acetylene dicarboxylic acid and 56 mg (1 mmol) of potassium hydroxide in 2 mL of MeOH and 8 mL of water) followed by 113 mg (0.25 mmol) of solid tpbn. After stirring for 15 min, a white precipitate appeared. The reaction mixture was stirred for another 4 h at room temperature. A white solid was collected via filtration, washed with methanol and water, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 123 mg (55.6%).

Method II

In a 25 mL RBF, 60.2 mg (0.25 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2 was dissolved in 6 mL of methanol and 56.5 mg (0.125 mmol) of solid tpbn was added to it. Solid H2adc (14.2 mg, 0.125 mmol) was added to the resulting clear solution, and a white precipitate was formed under stirring for 2 h. The mixture was stirred further for 4 h to obtain a white solid that was filtered, washed with methanol, and dried under vacuum. Yield: 60 mg (54.0%).

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>2</sub>(tppn)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>6</sub>](adc)<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

It can be prepared following either method I or method II described above for 1a. As is the case for 1a, the product formation is independent of the Mn(II) salt used. Therefore, one method is reported here. In a 10 mL RBF, 30.6 mg (0.125 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2, 27.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of tppn, and 14.2 mg (0.125 mmol) of H2adc were dissolved in 4 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for 3 h and then evaporated to dryness. The resulting residue was treated with a 1:1 mixture of acetonitrile and toluene (2 mL) to remove acetic acid completely, which provided an off-white solid. Yield: 41.5 mg (69.0%). Anal. Calcd for C35H48Mn2N6O17 (MW 934.67): C, 44.96; H, 5.13; N, 8.99. Found: C, 44.48; H, 4.67; N, 8.61. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3387, 3230, 1603, 1330, 775, 665. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [{Mn(tppn)}(adc)H]+, 606.56; found, 606.24.

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>2</sub>(adc)(1,2-tppn)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3a</bold>)

In a 10 mL RBF, 30.6 mg (0.125 mmol) of Mn(OAc)2, 55 mg (0.125 mmol) of 1,2-tppn, and 7.1 mg (0.0625 mmol) of H2adc were dissolved in 3 mL of methanol. The reaction mixture was allowed to stir for an hour, and then 30.5 mg (0.5 mmol) of sodium perchlorate was added to initiate precipitation. After the mixture was stirred for another 2 h, a white solid was collected via filtration, washed with methanol, and vacuum-dried. Yield: 40 mg (47.4%). Anal. Calcd for C58H62Cl2Mn2N12O15 (MW 1351): C, 51.52; H, 4.59; N, 12.43. Found: C, 51.90; H, 4.64; N, 12.34. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3430, 2926, 1615, 1602, 1570, 1436, 1319, 1087, 763, 675, 622. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [M – ClO4 –]+, 1197.23; found, 1197.12.

Synthesis of [Mn<sub>2</sub>(adc)(tpen)<sub>2</sub>](ClO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4a</bold>)

Compound 4a was synthesized following the method described for 3a except tpen was used instead of 1,2-tppn. Yield: 57 mg (67.8%). Anal. Calcd. for C56H56Cl2Mn2N12O14 (MW 1305): C, 51.49; H, 4.41; N, 12.89. Found: C, 51.26; H, 4.40; N, 12.59. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3446, 3067, 2921, 1617, 1602, 1571, 1436, 1322, 1087, 766, 758, 675, 623. MS (ESI-TOF): m/z calcd for [M – ClO4 –]+, 1168.59; found, 1169.02.

Synthesis of {[Mn<sub>2</sub>(adc)(tppen)(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>](adc)·4H<sub>2</sub>O}<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

Compound 5 was synthesized following the method described for 1a except tppen was used instead of tpbn. Yield: 41 mg (74%). Anal. Calcd. for C37H44Mn2N6O13 (MW 890): C, 49.88; H, 4.94; N, 9.43. Found: C, 49.96; H, 4.79; N, 9.74. It should be noted that the formula used for the calculation of CHN analysis was with one water molecule although other characterizations including X-ray crystallography indicated that it had four water molecules. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3392, 3220, 2935, 1626, 1604, 1570, 1482,1443, 1329, 1016, 777, 767, 665.

The first weight loss of 3.08% between 50 and 100 °C corresponds to one and a half lattice water molecules (ca. 3.15%). The second weight loss of 5.02% between 100 and 175 °C corresponds to one-half lattice water molecule and two coordinated water molecules (ca. 5.45%). The third weight loss of 33.95% between 175 and 450 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. For 2, the first weight loss of 10.90% observed between 45 and 105 °C corresponds to three free and three coordinated water molecules (ca. 11.61%). The second weight loss of 11.07% between 105 and 155 °C corresponds to decomposition of one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 12.20%). The third weight loss of 50.33% between 155 and 450 °C corresponds to three coordinated water molecules and one tppn ligand (ca.52.67%). This shows how strongly water molecules are hydrogen bonded with acetylene dicarboxylates in 2. For 5 (Figure S22 in the ), the first weight loss of 7.99% observed between 35 and 80 °C corresponds to four free water molecules (ca. 7.77%). The second weight loss of 21.14% between 80 and 190 °C corresponds to four coordinated water molecules and one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 19.70%). The third weight loss of 41.32% between 190 and 400 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. TGA of 3a and 4a were not carried out because these contain perchlorate anions. Thermal behavior of 1a, 2, and 5 are in very good agreement with X-ray studies as well as the FT-IR spectroscopic data.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analyses

For studying the thermal stability as a function of temperature, thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were conducted for the single phase polycrystalline samples of 1a and 2 between 25 and 500 °C under dinitrogen atmosphere (see Figures S20 and S21 in the , respectively). From the multistep decomposition process for 1a, it is clearly evident that lattice water molecules are lost first followed by the coordinated water molecules and the adc linker. The first weight loss of 3.08% between 50 and 100 °C corresponds to one and a half lattice water molecules (ca. 3.15%). The second weight loss of 5.02% between 100 and 175 °C corresponds to one-half lattice water molecule and two coordinated water molecules (ca. 5.45%). The third weight loss of 33.95% between 175 and 450 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. For 2, the first weight loss of 10.90% observed between 45 and 105 °C corresponds to three free and three coordinated water molecules (ca. 11.61%). The second weight loss of 11.07% between 105 and 155 °C corresponds to decomposition of one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 12.20%). The third weight loss of 50.33% between 155 and 450 °C corresponds to three coordinated water molecules and one tppn ligand (ca.52.67%). This shows how strongly water molecules are hydrogen bonded with acetylene dicarboxylates in 2. For 5 (Figure S22 in the ), the first weight loss of 7.99% observed between 35 and 80 °C corresponds to four free water molecules (ca. 7.77%). The second weight loss of 21.14% between 80 and 190 °C corresponds to four coordinated water molecules and one acetylene dicarboxylic acid (ca. 19.70%). The third weight loss of 41.32% between 190 and 400 °C indicates further decomposition of the dehydrated species. TGA of 3a and 4a were not carried out because these contain perchlorate anions. Thermal behavior of 1a, 2, and 5 are in very good agreement with X-ray studies as well as the FT-IR spectroscopic data.
